My apologies I have dropped the ball on this thread.  Been side tracked at =
work and now I'm back to this issue.  Did you still need me to create this =
bug?  If so, where do I need to submit this?

My solution I believe was to =
remove the timeout instead of doing each.get(2000, TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS); =
 I changed the source locally to each.get(); and the exception disappeared.=


I'm not certain this this is the right solution as I'm not completely fam=
iliar with the framework.  You may want a timeout feature but my feeling is=
 that it should somehow be configurable.  I would feel more comfortable if =
you or someone more experienced with this framework can make the fix.

Plea=
se let me know if 4.7 has this fix.

Thanks,
Mike


--- In junit@yahoogroup=

r part.

skilled in git, feel free to submit a patch.  Thanks for keeping us

t,

> On Thu, Apr 30, 2009 at 1:25 PM, mghongslo <mgho=
ngslo@...> wrote:
> > I'm reviewing the experimental functionality of runni=
ng parallel tests at the class level; i.e. Parallel.classes(), I notice in =
the ParallelComputer class, run() method there is a call get with a timeout=
 for 2000 milliseconds. Is there a significant reason for this versus get()=
 without any timeout? In conducting test without JUnit test cases, I'm find=
ing this timeout feature creates timeout exceptions whereas running JUnit w=
ithout the timeout allows my test to run successfully. Can anyone explain w=
hy this timeout is needed?
